title: What was Trump’s GPA at Wharton? - Quora

response.answer_text: UPDATE: It was recently revealed that Trump went to extraordinary lengths to hide his high school and college transcripts (see the end of this post). Gee, I wonder why… —- If I had to guess, I’d say that it wasn’t all that great. I base this on 4 factors: He transferred after 2 years at Fordham University. Fordham isn’t an especially academically-distinguished institution. Many people enroll at Fordham to be in New York City rather than for academic reasons (it’s easier to get into than Columbia or NYU). Even Trump’s transfer to U Penn’s Wharton is controversial. Biographer Gwenda Blair wrote that his admission was a special favor from an admissions officer who knew Trump’s brother. That would certainly make sense given Wharton’s high standards and Trump’s seeming intellectual mediocrity.Despite his millionaire father’s connections, he went to a mediocre private school in Queens, not some exclusive prep school in Manhattan or even a highly-rated one in Queens. Then his parents forced into military school for disobedience. While disobedience is not a direct indicator of grades, there’s a very good correlation. The key point is that it got bad enough for his parents to take such drastic action. Keep in mind that it wasn’t just boarding school, but military school, where discipline is key and freedom is very limited. Also note that Trump was banished to the New York Military Academy, not one of the more famous military academies (despite his dad being a real estate millionaire). That's another indicator of Trump’s academic mediocrity. Indeed, evidence of NYMA’s mediocrity is the fact that it went bankrupt a few years ago and was sold to Chinese investors. If it was a great school, you’d think that alumni and politicians would save it. Might this explain Trump’s financial antagonism toward China? Did military school change him for the better? There’s no data either way.His present behavior…ugh From the way he talks to his disdain for facts and science, he just doesn’t strike me as especially intelligent or academic. I mean, he doesn’t even lie very well. An intelligent liar would be more careful with his language, and choose lies that can’t be easily disproved. Three of Trump’s early lies were Obama’s foreign birthplace, inaugural crowd size and his margin of victory. All were easily proven against him within hours. As of November 2018, he had told 3500+ documented falsehoods (from exaggerations to outright lies).Furthermore, given his present lack of ethics, my guess is that he was one of the first to cheat when necessary. I base this on all the shady financial decisions he’s made, i.e. paying little to no personal taxes, exploiting the bankruptcy system, and designating his personal properties as farmland to avoid taxes. In the latter, he bought a few goats to graze on his NJ property and golf courses so that he can get farm tax breaks. In other words, he avoids paying taxes even though he provided none of the societal benefits of an actual farm. It may be legal but ethics is another story, since it deprives the community of income. Indeed, it borders on immoral when you consider that Trump is a billionaire, yet he feels fine depriving a town of $79,000??? To a small town, $79,000 can do a lot, but is hardly noticeable to someone worth $3,500,000,000. Even the present Republican mayor thought it was dirty finances. Some may claim that these maneuvers actually show cleverness on Trump’s part. Hardly, since these things are usually devised by accountants and lawyers — with Trump’s approval. So he should take the ethical blame without getting any of the intellectual credit.Donald Trump, New Jersey Goat Herder?I’ve seen a couple of interviews with former Wharton and military classmates and none praised Trump’s intelligence or academic prowess. In fact, a U Penn article interviewed 13 of his Wharton classmates and only one remembered him. And it was apparently a very different low key Donald Trump. In short, all of the classmates thought that he was probably undistinguished and even an underachiever. Notably, the rather negative article was written in 2015, when Trump’s reputation was nowhere as bad as it is now.All said, although I have no evidence of his grades, I’d say that it was below average — and that’s including probable cheating. And please note that Trump is fond of saying that he “went to some of the best schools.” The facts say otherwise. Only Wharton at UPenn fits that description and that was only for two years — and his acceptance there was likely a favor to his brother. ADDENDUM = as many have pointed out, you can’t compare your MBA grades to his. That’s because Trump doesn’t have an MBA. He attended Wharton for 2 years to complete an undergraduate degree in Economics. I’m sure he’s delighted, however, when people mistakenly believe that he has an MBA, or survived 4 years at Wharton. Why else won’t he mention his first 2 years at Fordham…?  UPDATE -It was recently revealed by Trump’s former lawyer, Michael Cohen, that Trump went through remarkable efforts to prevent his military academy and college grades from being revealed. That, despite demanding that Obama release his Harvard transcripts. Hypocrisy! Furthermore, Trump constantly boasts about his own intelligence and education. So what is he ashamed of? https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/03/05/extensive-effort-bury-donald-trumps-grades/?utm_term=.2544a0e2ca85 Jimmy Kimmel: Trump’s secret high school grades revealed. HAHA

Donald Trump’s GPA at Wharton was nothing spectacular. A high GPA is usually complimented by graduation with honors. However, Trump’s name was evidently not on the Dean’s list of Wharton.  Does that totally discredit Donald Trump’s intelligence? Not necessarily. Did Trump inflate his own academic history? Yes. Now let’s think of a more abstract idea. How did Trump get into the prestigious Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania? A school with a 9% acceptance rate, getting in is no easy task. Well first off, he only completed his undergraduate at Wharton in two years after transferring.  Trump transferred from Fordham college at Rose Hill. Now, his college years here are somewhat of a mystery. The way I look at it is since he transferred, what exactly were his stats that made him qualified to get in? What GPA did he earn in those two years at Fordham? These days transferring to a prestigious university is extremely difficult. Back then I believe it was just as hard. However, one biographer, Gwenda Blair, claims Trump was admitted to Wharton on a “special favor.” That being a possible hefty donation of $1.4 million to UPenn. With that as a part of his transfer application, grades now seem less important in the admission process. Overall, the whole college years of Trump are somewhat mysterious. We are left to assume he must have had good enough stats to meet transfer requirements and was decent enough to graduate with a B.S in Economics in 1968.  I think that when people get wrapped up in who had the highest GPA, people start looking like high school freshmen again. “I have a 3.8 and you have a 3.6 therefore I’m way smarter than you.” “Oh and Billy there, he has a 4.0, he's probably gonna be an astronaut or a brain surgeon with those grades.” In the end GPA is one way to measure academic success. Inflating your own grades, that’s poor academic integrity. It’s also inaccurate when New York Times reports in 1973–1976 that he graduated “first in his class” when his GPA was probably around 3.4~3.5. "I decided that as long as I had to be in college, I might as well test myself against the best," he explains in his 1989 autobiography, "The Art of the Deal." (This was purely a research post, I take no side in political arguments).
